conclusion: Understanding the setup with two sliders connected by a rope on an inclined plane with a horizontal force applied to slider B.
Recognizing that the sliders are on the verge of sliding upwards, indicating balanced forces.
Considering the inclined plane angle of 37 degrees and the role of normal and gravitational force components.
Acknowledging the importance of friction force in the problem.
Drawing a free-body diagram for slider A with weight, normal force, friction force, and tension.
Drawing a free-body diagram for slider B with weight, normal force, friction force, tension, and applied force.
Resolving forces into components parallel and perpendicular to the inclined plane for slider A.
Calculating net force on slider A parallel to the plane as mg sinθ - f_A - T.
Setting net force on slider A to zero since it's on the verge of sliding upwards.
Resolving forces into components parallel and perpendicular to the inclined plane for slider B.
Calculating net force on slider B parallel to the plane as mg sinθ - f_B - T + F cosθ.
Setting net force on slider B to zero since it's on the verge of sliding upwards.
Expressing tension T from equation for slider A as T = mg sinθ - f_A.
Substituting tension T into equation for slider B and simplifying.
Simplifying equation to - f_B + f_A + F cosθ = 0.
Using friction force formula f = μ N with μ = 0.5.
Substituting friction forces f_A and f_B into the equation.
Factoring out μ to get μ (N_A - N_B) + F cosθ = 0.
Finding expression for normal force N_A for slider A as N_A = mg cosθ.
